Definition: You will be given a public comment from an online platform. Your task is to classify the comment as either a 'threat' or 'non-threat'. A 'threat' is a statement that someone will be hurt or harmed if they do not do something in particular.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Enough already.  Cut the head off this snake.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment conveys a violent threat to someone.

Positive Examples.input: Comment: Disgusting comment, I pity anyone who has to live with you.
Positive Examples.explanation: This comment might be toxic but is not a threat to anyone.

Negative Examples.input:
Comment: Bravo!  Bravo!

Encore!! Encore!! Encore!!
Negative Examples.explanation: This comment is clearly unrelated to threat.

Comment: It is not possible to falsify a general argument by quoting a single person or a few people who have personal opinions that align with your own.  Ultimately, whether or not something is accurate and truthful depends upon careful review, analysis and interpretation of evidence over a significant period of time.

Many people (and organizations) do not recognize when they make assumptions or make statements or they engage in behavior that is perceived by a minority group as hurtful or hostile toward their community.  Instead of constantly telling us that the JBS always expels racists and anti-semites (which is false) you might (just once) acknowledge that the JBS has welcomed racists and anti-semites into its ranks as chapter leaders, as Coordinators, as National Council members, as authors and as speakers.  That simply is indisputable.

Furthermore, the JBS circulated arguments that originated with bigots -- such as their attack on Highlander Folk School and Martin Luther King Jr.
